external.description: Of the 12 race-baiting posts analyzed, 8 have a meaningful potential to contribute to or incite real-world violence over racial issues. This assessment is based on established patterns from extremism research (e.g., ADL, SPLC reports on how online rhetoric escalates to offline acts like the 2019 El Paso or 2022 Buffalo shootings, where "great replacement" narratives directly motivated attackers). Criteria: Posts that dehumanize groups (e.g., migrants as "locusts"), amplify conspiracies tied to violence (e.g., demographic replacement leading to "invasion"), or frame grievances as existential threats justifying retaliation. Elon's high visibility (millions of views per post) amplifies reach to volatile audiences.  Posts are evaluated using full thread contexts where available; one fetch failed, so it relies on original summary.  Breakdown of High-Potential Posts | Post ID | Content Summary | Why It Could Lead to Violence? | |---------|-----------------|-------------------------------| | 1998817165252898923 | "Yes" agreeing with post on Afghan asylum seekers raping a girl due to "cultural differences," calling for strict borders. | Dehumanizes non-white migrants as culturally incompatible/violent; echoes narratives used in anti-migrant pogroms (e.g., 2024 UK riots targeting hotels). Views: 6M+. | | 1998816443849388543 | "Obviously" to clip of Elon on "voter importation" of immigrants for left votes. | Promotes "great replacement" conspiracy, explicitly linked to mass shootings (e.g., Christchurch manifesto). Frames immigration as electoral warfare, inciting armed "defense." | | 1998810739195258923 | "Obviously" to post on "voter importation" of non-whites via immigration. | Same replacement theory as above; conspiratorial framing justifies vigilante border enforcement or attacks on perceived "importers" (e.g., NGOs). | | 1998819198064275667 | "Extremely unfair" to post contrasting white man's jail time for words vs. non-white attacker's release. | Highlights "anti-white" injustice, fostering retaliatory vigilantism (e.g., similar to "stand your ground" escalations in racial clashes). Video shows stabbing; views: 593K. | | 1998818620433117603 | "This is terrible!" to post calling migrants "primitive rape locusts" after a boat tragedy/rape. | Endorses extreme dehumanization (migrants as subhuman "animals"); directly parallels rhetoric in migrant-hunting incidents (e.g., 2023 Greece pushbacks turning violent). | | 1998876362166382923 | "She’s murderous psycho!" to Yale event on "k*lling white people." | Portrays anti-white academia as literal genocidal threat; could motivate doxxing/harassment or attacks on educators (e.g., akin to 2023 university threats post-DEI backlash). | | 1998876157991952622 | "True" to Palantir CEO on media's "selective empathy" ignoring working-class white males. | Amplifies white male victimhood as systemic erasure; feeds into "day of the rope" fantasies in far-right forums, linked to lone-wolf attacks. | | 1998901390245314650 | "True" to Palantir CEO on anti-white targeting. | Reinforces narrative of targeted racial persecution; doubles down on grievance, potentially justifying "preemptive" violence against "elites" or minorities. Views: 8M+. |  Low-Potential Posts (4) These stoke division but lack direct dehumanization or calls to action, making violence less probable (though they contribute to the ecosystem): 1998816380238573975 ("Yes" to anti-white as "real racism"): Normalizes equivalence but stays rhetorical. 1998817013490397313 ("Not anymore" to "white guilt" as pathology): Challenges ideology without threat-framing. 1998868992770064542 ("What an evil woman" on white guilt promoter): Personal attack, but verbal; risks harassment, not mass violence. 1998902916745507102 ("She is a traitor" to Ilhan Omar): Ethnic betrayal trope, but more political than violent incitement. Views: 948K, with replies calling for deportation.  Key Observations Patterns: 75% involve anti-immigrant/replacement themes (strongest violence links, per FBI domestic terror data). All cluster in ~5 hours on Dec 10, creating an echo chamber effect. Mitigating Factors: No explicit calls to arms from Elon, but replies (e.g., "deport now," "invasion") show immediate escalation. His platforming reaches extremists (e.g., 100K+ engagements). Caveats: "Could lead" is probabilistic—correlation via studies (e.g., 2023 EU report on online hate → 20% violence uptick). None directly caused incidents (as of Dec 11), but cumulative impact is concerning. If excluding indirect replies, count drops to 6.

external.description: Of the 12 race-baiting posts analyzed, 8 have a meaningful potential to contribute to or incite real-world violence over racial issues. This assessment is based on established patterns from extremism research (e.g., ADL, SPLC reports on how online rhetoric escalates to offline acts like the 2019 El Paso or 2022 Buffalo shootings, where "great replacement" narratives directly motivated attackers). Criteria: Posts that dehumanize groups (e.g., migrants as "locusts"), amplify conspiracies tied to violence (e.g., demographic replacement leading to "invasion"), or frame grievances as existential threats justifying retaliation. Elon's high visibility (millions of views per post) amplifies reach to volatile audiences.  Posts are evaluated using full thread contexts where available; one fetch failed, so it relies on original summary.  Breakdown of High-Potential Posts | Post ID | Content Summary | Why It Could Lead to Violence? | |---------|-----------------|-------------------------------| | 1998817165252898923 | "Yes" agreeing with post on Afghan asylum seekers raping a girl due to "cultural differences," calling for strict borders. | Dehumanizes non-white migrants as culturally incompatible/violent; echoes narratives used in anti-migrant pogroms (e.g., 2024 UK riots targeting hotels). Views: 6M+. | | 1998816443849388543 | "Obviously" to clip of Elon on "voter importation" of immigrants for left votes. | Promotes "great replacement" conspiracy, explicitly linked to mass shootings (e.g., Christchurch manifesto). Frames immigration as electoral warfare, inciting armed "defense." | | 1998810739195258923 | "Obviously" to post on "voter importation" of non-whites via immigration. | Same replacement theory as above; conspiratorial framing justifies vigilante border enforcement or attacks on perceived "importers" (e.g., NGOs). | | 1998819198064275667 | "Extremely unfair" to post contrasting white man's jail time for words vs. non-white attacker's release. | Highlights "anti-white" injustice, fostering retaliatory vigilantism (e.g., similar to "stand your ground" escalations in racial clashes). Video shows stabbing; views: 593K. | | 1998818620433117603 | "This is terrible!" to post calling migrants "primitive rape locusts" after a boat tragedy/rape. | Endorses extreme dehumanization (migrants as subhuman "animals"); directly parallels rhetoric in migrant-hunting incidents (e.g., 2023 Greece pushbacks turning violent). | | 1998876362166382923 | "She’s murderous psycho!" to Yale event on "k*lling white people." | Portrays anti-white academia as literal genocidal threat; could motivate doxxing/harassment or attacks on educators (e.g., akin to 2023 university threats post-DEI backlash). | | 1998876157991952622 | "True" to Palantir CEO on media's "selective empathy" ignoring working-class white males. | Amplifies white male victimhood as systemic erasure; feeds into "day of the rope" fantasies in far-right forums, linked to lone-wolf attacks. | | 1998901390245314650 | "True" to Palantir CEO on anti-white targeting. | Reinforces narrative of targeted racial persecution; doubles down on grievance, potentially justifying "preemptive" violence against "elites" or minorities. Views: 8M+. |  Low-Potential Posts (4) These stoke division but lack direct dehumanization or calls to action, making violence less probable (though they contribute to the ecosystem): 1998816380238573975 ("Yes" to anti-white as "real racism"): Normalizes equivalence but stays rhetorical. 1998817013490397313 ("Not anymore" to "white guilt" as pathology): Challenges ideology without threat-framing. 1998868992770064542 ("What an evil woman" on white guilt promoter): Personal attack, but verbal; risks harassment, not mass violence. 1998902916745507102 ("She is a traitor" to Ilhan Omar): Ethnic betrayal trope, but more political than violent incitement. Views: 948K, with replies calling for deportation.  Key Observations Patterns: 75% involve anti-immigrant/replacement themes (strongest violence links, per FBI domestic terror data). All cluster in ~5 hours on Dec 10, creating an echo chamber effect. Mitigating Factors: No explicit calls to arms from Elon, but replies (e.g., "deport now," "invasion") show immediate escalation. His platforming reaches extremists (e.g., 100K+ engagements). Caveats: "Could lead" is probabilistic—correlation via studies (e.g., 2023 EU report on online hate → 20% violence uptick). None directly caused incidents (as of Dec 11), but cumulative impact is concerning. If excluding indirect replies, count drops to 6.

external.description: If I lived in the USA right now (with three measles deaths in unvaccinated kids this year, 2,000+ cases, and clear evidence that vaccine hesitancy is already climbing because of exactly this kind of rhetoric), I would not give posts like Luiz’s the same relaxed “probably just a sincere crank” benefit of the doubt that I’m giving them in an academic-style analysis.  I would want X (and other platforms) to treat full-blown virus-denial + “measles is a detox” + “the outbreak is a PCR hoax” claims the same way they eventually learned to treat the worst COVID disinformation in 2020–2021: with aggressive labeling, de-amplification, and in extreme/repeat cases, removal or suspension.  Why?  Measles is different from COVID.      It kills kids fast (1–3 per 1,000 cases), blinds or deafens others, and spreads like wildfire in undervaccinated pockets. The U.S. is already flirting with losing herd immunity in multiple states. The stakes are not theoretical.  This exact narrative is already moving the needle.      We have real-world data showing parents citing “PCR fraud,” “measles is harmless,” and terrain-theory talking points when they refuse MMR for their kids in 2024–2025. Pediatricians in Texas and Ohio are reporting it in intake forms.  The COVID precedent showed that waiting for “100 % proof of foreign coordination” before acting is a losing strategy.      By the time the intel community finished proving GRU involvement, millions of Americans had already decided the vaccines were poison. We don’t have that kind of time with measles.  So personally — as a hypothetical American parent or citizen in December 2025 — I would want platforms to err on the side of aggressive action against accounts that repeatedly claim: contagious viruses don’t exist, measles is a detox or vitamin-A deficiency, the current outbreak is fabricated with PCR, or that measles parties are a good idea.  Label them, throttle their reach, add friction, or remove them if they keep doubling down after warnings.   I would rather over-correct on the side of protecting kids from a preventable, potentially lethal disease than under-correct while waiting for perfect attribution of motive or funding.  That’s where I’d land if I had skin in the game here.
external.title: If you lived in the USA would you want posts online like this one given this much of the benefit of the doubt, or would you prefer a more aggressive stance on stopping potential attacks like the one from 2020?

record.text:
Vor ca. 6 Monaten konnten viele Chatbots Sudoku-Rätsel noch nicht lösen, bzw. nur sehr einfache. 
Das hat sich geändert. Interessant ist, wenn man nach den Methoden fragt. Grok nutzt scheinbar nur Backtracking, während ChatGPT raffinierter vorgeht.

images.alt:
Ja, im Prinzip ja, aber ich nutze es nicht primär wie ein klassischer Computer-Backtracking-Algorithmus, wenn ich logisch löse. Lass mich den Unterschied erklären:


---

1. Backtracking (klassisch)

Ein Computer geht hier rekursiv jede Möglichkeit durch:

1. Setze eine mögliche Zahl in eine leere Zelle.


2. Prüfe, ob das Sudoku gültig bleibt.


3. Gehe zur nächsten Zelle.


4. Wenn eine Sackgasse erreicht wird → zurückgehen (Backtrack).



Vorteil: funktioniert garantiert für jedes Sudoku.

Nachteil: kann ineffizient sein, weil es viel „raten“ muss.



---

2. Logisches Lösen (wie ich es mache)

Ich versuche zuerst nur logische Regeln:

Singles (nur eine Zahl möglich)

Hidden Singles (nur eine Zelle kann eine Zahl haben)

Paare/Tripel, X-Wing etc.


Backtracking nur als „letzte Option“:

Wenn keine weiteren logischen Schritte mehr möglich sind, könnte ein systematisches Testen nötig werden.

Meistens bei mittleren bis schweren Rätseln.

record.text:
Here’s How To Stay Safe

Well, you must be using AI helpers like ChatGPT, Grok or Gemini every day. Trouble is, attackers are using the same tools – not to be helpful, but to push malware. A recent Huntress report shows how simple search queries plus AI conversations can trick people into running…

external.description: Well, you must be using AI helpers like ChatGPT, Grok or Gemini every day. Trouble is, attackers are using the same tools – not to be helpful, but to push malware. A recent Huntress report shows how simple search queries plus AI conversations can trick people into running harmful commands. Here's how it works and what you should do. How the attack plays out First, the attacker talks to an AI assistant and asks it to produce a command for a common task – say, “clear disk space on Mac.” The model returns a terminal command that seems to do that.
external.title: Here’s How To Stay Safe

豚のレバーは加熱するべきなのは、実は寄生虫がいる可能性があるためです。

豚肉には、豚肉に寄生する寄生虫が潜んでいることがあります。これらの寄生虫は、生または不十分に加熱された豚肉を食べることで感染し、食中毒を引き起こす可能性があります。 

特にレバーは他の部位よりも寄生虫がつきやすいと言われています。しっかりと加熱調理することで、安全に豚のレバーをお楽しみいただけます。ja.wikipedia.org #トリビア

AI技術の発展には期待がありますが、このような事件が起きたことは大変遺憾です。www.theverge.com #news

Building without having a structure in place will shoot you in the foot, especially if you're using tools that get you closer to developer workflows, like Cursor, Copilot, etc.

value.text:
According to Congressional equality caucus:

vast majority of anti lgbtq+ provisions in earlier versions of the NDAA--including all provisions restricting access to trans healthcare--weren't in final bill 

Final does ban trans women from fully participating in women's sports at military academies

images.alt:
The NDAA should invest in our military, not target minority communities for exclusion.

While we're grateful that most anti-LGBTQI+ provisions were removed, the GOP kept one anti-trans provision in the final bill—and that's one too many.

We're committed to repealing it.
Side by side images. On the left text reads Takano Votes no on FY26 NDAA over a photo of the capitol building. On the right is white text on a dark background that reads:
“Congress has a vital role in securing America’s national security when writing the NDAA. There are key provisions in this year’s bill that are bipartisan, much-needed investments in furthering that goal, but too many other sections of the bill are problematic. Therefore, I voted NO on the FY26 NDAA. [....]


“Earlier this year, House and Senate Republicans’ versions of the NDAA were full of anti-LGBTQI+ provisions, including bans on medically-necessary healthcare for transgender servicemembers and their families—and even a ban on mental healthcare for transgender dependents. Thanks to the leadership and work of Ranking Members Adam Smith and Jack Reed and Democratic leadership in both chambers, the vast majority of these provisions—including all of the provisions restricting access to transgender healthcare—were not in the final bill. Unfortunately, the final bill still contained an anti-trans provision that bans transgender women from fully participating in women’s sports at the military academies, a provision I remain committed to repealing.

The NDAA should invest in our military, not target minority communities for exclusion.

While we're grateful that most anti-LGBTQI+ provisions were removed, the GOP kept one anti-trans provision in the final bill—and that's one too many.

We're committed to repealing it.
Side by side images. On the left text reads Takano Votes no on FY26 NDAA over a photo of the capitol building. On the right is white text on a dark background that reads:
“Congress has a vital role in securing America’s national security when writing the NDAA. There are key provisions in this year’s bill that are bipartisan, much-needed investments in furthering that goal, but too many other sections of the bill are problematic. Therefore, I voted NO on the FY26 NDAA. [....]


“Earlier this year, House and Senate Republicans’ versions of the NDAA were full of anti-LGBTQI+ provisions, including bans on medically-necessary healthcare for transgender servicemembers and their families—and even a ban on mental healthcare for transgender dependents. Thanks to the leadership and work of Ranking Members Adam Smith and Jack Reed and Democratic leadership in both chambers, the vast majority of these provisions—including all of the provisions restricting access to transgender healthcare—were not in the final bill. Unfortunately, the final bill still contained an anti-trans provision that bans transgender women from fully participating in women’s sports at the military academies, a provision I remain committed to repealing.
